text: To characterize further the function of the intracellular <extra_id_0> vitamin D receptor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> VDR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) , we have developed stable transfectant variants of a vitamin D - responsive cell line ( U937 ) which express either decreased or increased numbers of <extra_id_0> VDR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

text: In this study we have analyzed changes in gene expression associated with this variable <extra_id_0> VDR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression .

Initial experiments indicated that a 50 % decrease in <extra_id_0> VDR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> levels was associated with a 2-fold increase in cell proliferation and a similar rise in <extra_id_0> c-myc <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA expression .

text: Further studies were carried out using differential RNA display ( DD ) .

Sequence analysis of DD products revealed two cDNAs with identity to known gene products : the catalytic sub-unit of DNA - protein kinase ( <extra_id_0> DNA-PK(CS) <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) , and the peroxisomal enzyme <extra_id_0> 17beta-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase type IV <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> 17beta-HSD IV <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) .
Northern analysis confirmed that expression of both mRNAs was reduced in cells with decreased numbers of <extra_id_0> VDR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

Down-regulation of <extra_id_0> 17beta-HSD IV <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA expression was associated with enhanced estradiol inactivation by U937 cells , suggesting a link between estrogenic pathways and cell proliferation .

text: Further Northern analyses indicated that there was no significant change in <extra_id_0> 17beta-HSD IV <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> or <extra_id_0> DNA-PK(CS) <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA levels following treatment with 1 , 25 ( OH ) 2D3 , although expression of both genes varied with changes in cell proliferation .

text: These data suggest that , in addition to its established role as a hormone - dependent trans - activator , <extra_id_0> VDR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> may influence gene expression by ligand - independent mechanisms .
